source.b22d0c6e:
#Determinants of diabetes mellitus in the Pima Indians.
Authors: Knowler WC1, Saad MF, Pettitt DJ, Nelson RG, Bennett PH.

Pima Indians in Arizona have participated in a longitudinal diabetes study that has provided data on and hypotheses about the development of NIDDM.(Non-insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus - NIDDM ). Findings from this study are reviewed and updated.

Frequency distributions of plasma glucose and HbA1(Hemoglobin, Alpha 1) are bimodal in Pima adults, and substantial risk of the specific vascular complications of diabetes is confined to those in the higher components of these distributions. These findings contributed to the adoption of internationally recognized criteria for classification of glucose tolerance. Diabetes in the Pimas is strongly familial, and probably of genetic origin, although the precise nature of the gene or genes involved remains unknown. Obesity, which is at least in part environmentally determined, is a major factor interacting with the presumed genetic susceptibility to result in diabetes.
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/8422779
